Marien Torres discusses joining the bomba ensemble Plenibom in college led by Norma Salazar and being arrested for protesting in 1999.
Diegetic saxophone music plays as images of La Fortaleza in Viejo San Juan are shown

At Museo de San Juan, Marien Torres’ dance classes present a re-enactment of the Vieques military occupation protests. The choreography explores the tension and resistance of that historic moment: some dancers embody military figures, their arms rigidly posed like rifles, while others portray the resisters. Through movement, the dancers evoke the emotional and political struggle of the protests, transforming the studio into a living archive of Puerto Rican resistance.

Marien Torres discusses the impact of Puerto Rico's soundscape which consisted of chicken cries that changed after hurricane Maria and also how even these animals exemplify resilience. She also discusses how the water flooded her house and her new house which is quite empty

Cary Cepeda discusses the suffering, and labor required of carrying on the legacy of bomba. They had to carry heavy drums very far to neighboring towns.
